conclusion: Need to analyze the circuit both when the switch S is open and when it is closed.
When the switch S is open, the circuit is divided into two separate loops. The voltmeter is connected across the 20Ω resistor, and it reads 6V.
Using Ohm's Law, the current through the 20Ω resistor is calculated as 0.3A.
The current through the 20Ω resistor is the same as the current through the battery because the circuit is in series when the switch is open.
The total voltage across the battery and internal resistance r is 6V.
When the switch S is closed, the 10Ω resistor is added in parallel with the 20Ω resistor. The resistance R is in series with this parallel combination.
The equivalent resistance of the 10Ω and 20Ω resistors in parallel is calculated as approximately 6.67Ω.
The total resistance in the circuit when the switch is closed is the sum of the equivalent resistance and R.
The voltage across points a and b when the switch is closed is the same as the voltage across the parallel combination of the 10Ω and 20Ω resistors, which is 6V.
The voltage between points a and b when the switch S is closed is 6V.
